defs: Kailāsa, the snow-clad mountain.
a kind of sedge grass.
its root.
a kind of plant.
the plant Calotropis gigantea ( = C. procera) of Asclepidaceae family.
the tree Terminalia arjuna ( = T. glabra) of Combretaceae family; Arjuna myrobalan.
name of one of the upanishads.
(gen. pronounced with the vowel 'ಆ') the forty fifth letter of Kannaḍa alphabet and the thirty first consonant.
(math.) a symbol for the number six.
a group of trees or plants.
a bull set at liberty.
any man or boy lacking normal function of the testes; an eunuch.
(fig.) a timid, faintherted or fearful man.
(jain.) the neuter gender; a word or form in this gender.
lack of normal function of the testes; the quality or state of being an eunuch.
lack of courage; the quality of being timid, coward; cowardice.
(gram.) the neuter gender; a word or form in this gender.
(fig.) a useless fellow or he who has shamefully excessive fear of danger.

the letter or the sound of the letter "ಷ".
a doubt; a suspicion.

a group or set of six (of the same kind).
= ಷಟ್ಚಕ್ರ.
the six daily duties of a brāhmaṇa - studying of the vedas, teaching of the vedas, offering sacrifices, conducting of sacrifices for others, giving of gits, and accepting of gifts.

(according to another school) the six daily duties of a brāhmaṇa are religious bathing, repetition of prayers three times a day, worshipping of the Supreme Being, daily oblations to the gods, sages and dead ancestors and oblations of fuel, rice etc. to fire, and worshipping of the secondary gods either at home or in temples.
the six principal occupation of olden days - military service, giving education, agriculture, commerce (& trade), construction, and animal husbandry.

a brāhmaṇa who performs the six daily duties - a) studying of the vedas, teaching of the vedas, offering sacrifices, conducting of sacrifices for others, giving of gits, and accepting of gifts or, b) religious bathing, repetition of prayers three times a day, worshipping of the Supreme Being, daily oblations to the gods, sages and dead ancestors and oblations of fuel, rice etc. to fire, and worshipping of the secondary gods either at home or in temples.
(jain.) the six affected-states of the mind - jovial mood, impassioned mood, displeasure, grief, fear and abhorrence.
the area of a hexagon.
(pl.) the six divisions of the earth.
(pl.) the six continents - Asia, Africa, Europe, North America, South America and Australia.
(pl.) the six mystical circles in the human body, which has the latent energy, when aroused, passes through and reach the pinnacle at which it merges with the universal Energy.
= ಷಟ್ಪದ - 1.
the body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) of the head louse (Pediculus humanus capitis).
the six principal schools of Indian philosophy.
amounting to thirty six.
the cardinal number thirty six.
a bee (that has six legs).
any of several varieties of metrical verses each having six lines.

a female bee.
the body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) or the head louse (Pediculus humanus capitis).
a man who has good knowledge of the four ideals of life (righteousness, economic life, human enjoyments, final emancipation), practical knowledge of life's hard facts, and philosophy.
(vīr.) the six progressive stages in achieving the oneness with Śiva.
= ಷಟ್ಸ್ಥಲ.
the four divisions of human army (viz. elephants, chariots, cavalry and infantry), the army of the gods and that of Khēcaras (a class of beings who travel in the sky).
the six principal parts f the body (the two arms, two legs, head and waist).
the six things obtained from a cow (milk, curd, ghee, urine, dung and an yellow pigment prepared from its bile).
the six vēdangas (a group of texts dealing with six subjects that are considered essential for the understanding of the vedas).
a man who is versed in the six vēdangas (a group of texts dealing with six subjects that are considered essential for an understanding of the vedas).

a ornamental tuft of hairs, feathers, etc. for decorating cattle, horses, etc.

a set of six vices (as lust, anger, avrice, fondness (infatuation), arrogance and jealosy) considered as the enemies within.

the respective places of these mystic circles.

the six medicinal plants or their parts viz. Plumbago zeylanica, dried wood of Cleistanthus collinus, the rhizome of Zingiber cassumunnar, helleborus niger, Acotinum heterophyllum and myrobalan.

(pl.) the six seasons of the year (each of which is of two months period, starting from the beginning of Caitra).

the six things obtained from a cow (milk, curd, ghee, urine, dung and an yellow pigment got from its bile).
(pl.) the qualities percieved by the senses and the mind.
the six excellencies or advantages, viz. beauty or handsomeness, education, mettle, knowledge, good fortune, and ownership of land.
the six acts or measures to be practised by a king in a warfare, viz. peace, war, marching, sitting encamped, dividing his forces and seeking the protection from a more powerful king.
the six merits disposition of forgiving, compassion, peacefulness, tolerance, truthfulness and steadfastness.
to become six-fold.
to cause to increase by six times.

produced with the help of the tongue, teeth, palate, nose, throat and chest.

a man as related to the husband of one's wife's sister.
the relation that exists between the husbands of two sisters.
the six principal schools of Indian philosophy.
a species of poisonous worm.
(hist.) the sixth part of produce, income, etc. that one had to pay to the ruler as tax.
the six stages of life, viz. birth, existence, growth, change in the form, becoming weak and death.
a plane figure with six angles and six sides; a hexagon.

its fruit; sweet melon; musk melon.

the letter or the sound of the letter "ಷ".
a military attack carried on during night times.
the garment worn by boys or men (by girls too) on the upper part of the body, having a collar, either full or half-leeves, and a buttoned opening down the front.
a pledge of a forfeit risked on some uncertain outcome; a wager; a bet.
anything called for as a requirement before the performance or completion of something else; a stipulation; a condition.
